item.title: What! So What! Now What!
item.description: Introduction Here’s some simple advice that, once said, makes so much sense that I wonder if it really needs saying. When you’re delivering a key message or report in a work environment, consider adopting the “What, So What, Now What” framework. Take, as an example, a demand review presentation when the Demand Manager presents the demand plan update. If you’re unfamiliar with the S&OP structure, the objective of the monthly demand review is to achieve consensus on sales plans and forecasts that are then published to the broader business.

item.title: Forecasting During a Pandemic - IBF Webinar
item.description: Introduction COVID-19 presents demand planning with plenty of challenges, though it also might present opportunities. An example given in the introduction to this webinar was of Isaac Newton, a mere college student at Cambridge University when the campus closed in 1665 due to the Black Plague. While practicing the 1600’s version of social distancing, the curious and contemplative Newton formed his groundbreaking ideas on calculus, optics and gravity. These ideas were converted into theory when he returned to the reopened university in 1665.

item.title: Retrospective Reviews for Process Improvement: A Retrium Case Study
item.description: Introduction Last week, my team applied a new approach with great success to our performance retrospective. The approach worked so well that I’m standing up and evangelising the approach for a wider range of teams than those like our’s who apply Agile. Retrospective Goals and Objectives The goal of our sprint (i.e. our 3-week activity cycle) retrospective is to improve our systems and processes to drive business value.

item.title: Boutique forecasting for boutique beer
item.description: Introduction Boutique brewery numbers have exploded in Australia in the past 2 decades. So much so that the growth in demand for boutique brews has led corporate brewing companies, CUB, Lion, Asahi and Coca Cola Amatil, to acquire and establish their own boutique beer brands. Data taken from http://craftbeerreviewer.com/the-brewery-list/ shows that 701 boutique brewing brands now operate around Australia. While I’m yet to find data on the historical growth of craft beers in Australia, Goldstein Research forecasts the Australian market to reach $345 million by 2025 with CAGR of over 5%.

item.title: Making MAPE More Meaningful
item.description: “You can’t manage what you can’t measure”, which is why it’s important for businesses to measure forecast accuracy. For those unaware, MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error) is one of the three most common forecast accuracy measures along with bias and MSE. It is also used as a proxy for measuring the demand planning value-add in an FMCG businesses. That is, when the MAPE score is favourable (low), then it is assumed that demand planning’s value-add for a business must be high.

item.title: Measuring Demand Planning Behaviours
item.description: What’s better; making the wrong decision for the right reasons or making the right decision for the wrong reasons? If it’s one-off, then the right decision for the wrong reasons (also known as a fluke), is likely to receive plaudits. However, if it’s part of a decision making process recurring every month, such as sales forecasting, then I’ll back the wrong decision for the right reasons (also known as bad luck) every time.

item.title: The Agile opportunity for Demand Planning Improvements
item.description: Demand planning team “going OK / not going OK”! A demand planner was recounting how her team was travelling OK but she felt that there was scope for significant improvement. For one thing, she felt that her team’s stakeholders didn’t really understand what the team did “beneath the bonnet” and would struggle to explain what value that they added to the business. There was, certainly, general satisfaction in the team’s output and people would say that, from the outside, that they were working well together, but that also reflected that stakeholders were somewhat unaware of the internal machinations.
